channel.title: University of Houston Downtown Events Calendar
channel.description: RSS Feed University of Houston Downtown Events Calendar

item.title: Winter Holidays, University Closed (12/25/2017 - 1/2/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 12/25/2017
End Date: 1/2/2018 End Time: Midnight
UHD will be closed for winter holidays from December 25, 2017 until January 2, 2018.

We will re-open for business on Wednesday, January 3, 2018.

item.title: Best Practices of Video Integration in Online & Hybrid Courses (1/4/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 1/4/2018 Start Time: 10:00 AM
End Date: 1/4/2018 End Time: 11:00 AM
This workshop is designed to help you use video more effectively in your online and hybrid classes. This session focuses on strategies to enhance instructor presence, engage students, and increase perceptions of enjoyment and learning. You will also learn the technical aspects of recording and sharing video with your students.

item.title: Blackboard Open Lab: Ready for Spring 2018 (1/5/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 1/5/2018 All Day
End Date: 1/5/2018
Come to this open lab and get help and tips from our team of Blackboard experts. This workshop will provide a space for you to ask questions about things like course copy, tests, and grades. No registration required.

item.description:
Start Date: 1/8/2018 Start Time: 3:00 PM
End Date: 1/8/2018 End Time: 4:00 PM
This workshop is designed to help you use video more effectively in your online and hybrid classes. This session focuses on strategies to enhance instructor presence, engage students, and increase perceptions of enjoyment and learning. You will also learn the technical aspects of recording and sharing video with your students.

item.title: Blackboard Foundations for Instructors Part I: Getting Started (1/9/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 1/9/2018 Start Time: 9:00 AM
End Date: 1/9/2018 End Time: 10:00 AM
The first part of this three-part course will get you familiar with the Blackboard Learn environment. In this session, you will learn how to use essential tools within the course and get tips and best practices to make your online/hybrid course a success. This session includes:
  • Getting Started
  • Navigating
  • Manage content

item.description:
Start Date: 1/11/2018 Start Time: 9:00 AM
End Date: 1/11/2018 End Time: 10:00 AM
In the third part of this three-part course, you will learn how to create assignments and tests/quizzes inside of Blackboard Learn. You will also learn how to grade, leave feedback, and effectively use the Student Preview tool. This session includes:
  • Create Assignments
  • Submit Assignments (student view)
  • Grade Assignments
  • Create Tests
  • Take Tests (student view)
  • Grade Tests
  • View Grades and Feedback (student view)

item.description:
Start Date: 1/23/2018 Start Time: 9:00 AM
End Date: 1/23/2018 End Time: 10:30 AM
The 2018 Performance Evaluation Cycle brings UHD staff new competencies tied to their job descriptions. These competencies align closely with UHD’s Mission and Values. To learn more about the new competencies and how they apply to individual performance, sign up for a New Competency Information Session.

item.title: Open House: Center for Public Service and Community Research (1/23/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 1/23/2018 Start Time: 9:30 AM
End Date: 1/23/2018 End Time: 12:00 PM
The Center for Public Service and Community Research Open House

Several of our community partners will be on hand to tell you about the various service learning and volunteer opportunities available to enhance your academic career. 

Agency/Name
  • HC Public Library
  • The Kid's  Reading Room
  • The Arc of Greater Houston
  • YMCA International Services
  • Generation One
  • PrisonEntrepreneurship Program
  • Santa Maria

Join us at the 2nd floor lobby of the Commerce Building to learn more!

For inquiries and more information, email CPSCR@uhd.edu

item.title: Jim McIngvale "Mattress Mack" awarded Social Work Program 2017 Person of the Year (1/25/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 1/25/2018 Start Time: 5:30 PM
End Date: 1/25/2018


On Thursday, January 25th at 5:30 p.m. here in the College of Public Service (C-100), the Social Work Program has the distinct honor of awarding their Person of the Year award to Houston’s own Jim McIngvale of Gallery Furniture. It was in 1981 that Mr. McIngvale, otherwise known as Mattress Mack, and his wife Linda, started Gallery Furniture with five thousand dollars and a dream. Mack began television advertising early on and with his motto of “Early to bed, early to rise, work like hell and advertise”, he quickly became a household name. 

 

If you live in Houston (and even if you don’t) you’ve no doubt heard of Mr. McIngvale’s generosity. During Hurricane Harvey, Mack sheltered many Houstonians in the Gallery Furniture facility. In fact, some of our very own faculty were assisted.

 

Please join us at 5:30 p.m. on Thursday, January 25th as we honor Jim McIngavle (aka Mattress Mack) as the 2017 UHD Social Work Person of the Year.

 

Some of Mack’s charitable contributions include:
  • Co-founded the Peace of Mind Foundation for those affected by Obsessive Compulsive Disorder 
  • Funded St. Luke’s Mobile Stroke Unit
  • Large contributor to Texas Heart Institute, Baylor College of Medicine and Harvard Medical School
  • Instrumental in getting Menninger Clinic to move to Houston to provide mental health care to Houston by providing a multi-million dollar donation
  • Fed 25,000 people Thanksgiving dinner for several years
  • Annual Christmas give-away furnishing hundreds of housefuls of furniture for the past 30 years
  • Bought 10,000 toys for needy children, distributed during the holiday
  • One of the largest contributors to the Houston Livestock Show & Rodeo with over $4 million given
  • Helped start and continuously fund the KickStart Kids Program in Houston
  • Furnished USO facilities around the world
  • Hosted events for and donated to the Salvation Army
  • Donated thousands of dollars of furniture to hundreds of teacher lounges in Houston area schools
  • Helped to raise over $12 million dollars for the Bush/Clinton fund to aid those affected by the Tsunami in Southeast Asia and Hurricanes Katrina and Rita
  • Underwrote YMCA playground at Reliant Stadium for Katrina Evacuees and housed several hundred evacuees during hurricane crisis
  • Underwrote National OCF Conference held in Houston
  • Recipient of Mental Health Association Award in 2005
  • Donated tennis racquets to inner city kids that would not otherwise have the opportunity to take tennis lessons

item.title: 3rd Annual Student Organization Leadership Development (SOLD) Conference (2/2/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/2/2018
End Date: 2/2/2018
The SOLD Conference is a comprehensive experience created for students and student leaders interested in enhancing their leadership and professional development skills.

Registration for the SOLD conference is now open to all students, student organizations, and student leaders. Advisors are also encouraged to attend. Registration will end at 5:00 p.m. on January 31, 2018.

Attendees to the event will receive:
  • Access to over 15 educational workshops and breakout sessions
  • Program book
  • Complimentary breakfast
  • Opening session featuring celebrity keynote speaker
  • Professional head shots
  • Networking reception

item.title: SOLD Conference (2/2/2018 - 2/3/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/2/2018 Start Time: 8:00 AM
End Date: 2/3/2018 End Time: 2:00 PM
The UHD Office of Student Activities is proud to host the 3rd Annual Student Organization Leadership Development (SOLD) Conference on February 2, 2018! The SOLD Conference is a comprehensive experience created for students and student leaders interested in enhancing their leadership and professional development skills. This conference features dynamic keynote speakers and provide student leaders with educational workshops and breakout sessions that focus on various leadership competencies and skills related to organization management, leadership and professional development. Students attending the conference will have the opportunity to engage in meaningful activities that will assist them in establishing positive, supportive and effective relationships with their advisors, peers, and community partners.

item.description:

item.title: 6th Biannual Forum on Plain English at UHD (2/9/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/9/2018 Start Time: 9:30 AM
End Date: 2/9/2018 End Time: 3:00 PM
We are pleased to invite you to participate in the sixth biannual Forum on Plain English organized by the Institute for Plain English Research and Study (IPERS) at UHD. The forum will be held at the University of Houston-Downtown, on February 9 (Friday, 9:30am-3:00pm), 2018. The forum aims to promote informed uses of Plain English guidelines, which are writing standards recommended by several government agencies for improved communications with the general public. Keynote Speaker: Leslie O’Flahavan is owner of E-WRITE, the writing training company she formed in 1996. Leslie is a plain language practitioner who helps customer care organizations for some of the world’s biggest brands write better email, chat, and social media to customers. She’s a customer service writing expert who can teach the most stubborn, inexperienced, or word-phobic frontline employees to improve their writing skills, so they can do their jobs better. As a result of her work, E-WRITE clients improve their customer satisfaction ratings, reduce training cycles, improve productivity, and limit legal risk. Leslie’s recent projects include helping Marriott launch live chat for their Sales IT Support team, training Air Canada’s 150+ Customer Relations agents to write in the airline’s updated brand voice, and writing a Social Media Guidebook for Hawaiian Airlines’ Reservations team. She’s helped thousands of employees apply plain language principles to their everyday work. Our one-day forum will address the following topics: • Customer Service Writing: Why Companies Should Use Plain Language in Emails, Chats, and Tweets to Customers • Seven Plain Language Practices That Will Release the Hot Air from Your Writing See the attached flyer for details. Registration deadline: Monday, February 5, 2018 Seating is limited. Register for the forum using our online registration: http://uhd.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_egSqVrr2gYdxKf3. Please provide your working email address so that we could contact you with parking instructions and campus maps.

FPE2018_Program.pdf

item.title: Black Cinema Series - Fences (2/13/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/13/2018 Start Time: 11:00 AM
End Date: 2/13/2018 End Time: 1:30 PM
Join the W.I. Dykes Library for a special back-to-back screening of 3 award nominated films in celebration of Black History Month! 

  • Fences @ 11:00 am - A working-class African-American father tries to raise his family in the 1950s, while coming to terms with the events of his life. Runtime: 2h 19min
  • Get Out @ 1:45 pm - It's time for a young African-American to meet with his white girlfriend's parents for a weekend in their secluded estate in the woods, but before long, the friendly and polite ambiance will give way to a nightmare. Runtime: 1h 44min
  • Moonlight @ 3:45 - A chronicle of the childhood, adolescence and burgeoning adulthood of a young, African-American, gay man growing up in a rough neighborhood of Miami. Runtime 1h 51min
Popcorn and refreshments provided!

Do you use Blackboard, Canvas, Brightspace by D2L, or Sakai as a learning management system? iClicker Cloud offers two options for integrating with your LMS: single-column grade sync and multiple-column grade sync (new in 2018!)

They will dig into how each integration is executed by campus administrators, instructors, and students. Natalie Dougall, Faculty Consultant and iClicker Trainer, will also discuss different pedagogical approaches to the grading process.

Register Here

item.title: Resolving the Breadth-depth-inquiry Dilemma in College Science Courses (2/15/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/15/2018 Start Time: 11:00 AM
End Date: 2/15/2018 End Time: 12:15 PM

Event Description:

Instructors of introductory science courses constantly face the dilemma of how to balance the coverage of diverse topics versus an in-depth treatment of key concepts, or spending time helping students learn how to do problem solving and scientific inquiry. We deploy a suite of approaches and assessment tools that allow us to simultaneously address these three competing aspects of breadth, depth, and inquiry. To address a breadth of topics, we provide students with a What-to-Know (WTK) List, and students are responsible for each item, even if that subject is not covered in lecture. This breadth of knowledge is assessed by weekly, online multiple-choice quizzes derived from items on the WTK List.



To assess deep knowledge, we provide students with a list of 12 possible concept-sketch questions for the next exam (three or four exams per semester). For each exam, we display two or three concept-sketch questions from the list, and students answer two questions, drawing and explaining each concept sketch on one side of the paper. Properly answering a concept-sketch question requires students to ahead of time develop complete answers — and therefore gain deep knowledge. For smaller classes, students are required to answer each concept-sketch question (intro courses) or item on the WTK List (upper-level courses) in a composition-book-sized portfolio that is collected and quickly graded for each exam. Use of these portfolios has dramatically increased student understanding and grades.



To assess inquiry skills, students complete each of the chapter-ending Investigations from the textbook, either online or on paper worksheets done in class and in small groups. Using this overall three-pronged approach, students are exposed to and assessed on a broad range of topics, but also need to have in-depth knowledge of 48 key topics. Freed from the requirement that we cover every topic during lectures, class time includes more active learning and time to develop problem-solving and inquiry skills, resolving the breadth-depth-inquiry dilemma.

Presenter Information (Reynolds & Johnson):

Dr. Stephen J. Reynolds received degrees in geosciences from University of Texas at El Paso and University of Arizona. He directed the geologic mapping program of the Arizona Geological Survey, where he produced a new geologic map of Arizona. He currently is a professor in the School of Earth and Space Exploration at Arizona State University, where he does research on cognition and learning, natural resources, and evolution of Southwestern landscapes. He has authored or edited over 200 maps, articles, and reports, ranging from tectonics to climate. He is the author of popular, award-winning textbooks, including Exploring Geology, Exploring Physical Geography, Exploring Earth Science, and Structural Geology of Rocks and Regions. He was President of the Arizona Geological Society and received outstanding alumni awards from UTEP and the University of Arizona.

Julia K. Johnson is a full-time faculty member in the School of Earth and Space Exploration at ASU. Her research involves geoscience education, structural geology, and regional geology. The main focus of her geoscience education research is on student- and instructor-generated sketches (concept sketches) for learning, teaching, and assessment in college geology classes. At ASU, she teaches Introduction to Geology to more than 2,000 students per year in in-person and online classes. Julia is recognized as one of the best science teachers at ASU, and has received student-nominated teaching awards and very high teaching evaluations in spite of her challenging classes. She gives talks and webinars to faculty members across the county about how to redesign their own classes to improve efficiency and student performance at the same time. Julia is coauthor of the Exploring Geology, Exploring Earth Science, and Exploring Physical Geography textbooks, Observing and Interpreting Geology (a lab manual), and publications on geology and science-education research, including an article in the Journal of Geoscience Education on concept sketches.



Room: N-602 (ESO Training Room). Contact Dr. Heinlein with any questions!

item.title: School Discipline and the Texas Criminal Code: School to Prison Pipeline? (2/15/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/15/2018 Start Time: 5:30 PM
End Date: 2/15/2018 End Time: 7:00 PM
School Discipline and the Texas Criminal Code: School to Prison Pipeline?

Presented Dr. Augustina Reyes

This talk will explore school discipline data to show that the way children are treated in school can help to set them on a path for later in life.  Students who are suspended in school are more likely to be arrested than students who are never suspended. Join us in following the school-to-prison pipeline from state policy to district policy to school leadership practices to the detention center. 

Followed by refreshments and a Q&A with Dr. Reyes

For more information contact: Steven Villano at villanos@uhd.edu

item.title: School Discipline and the Texas Criminal Code: School to Prison Pipeline? (2/15/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/15/2018 Start Time: 5:30 PM
End Date: 2/15/2018 End Time: 7:00 PM
School Discipline and the Texas Criminal Code: School to Prison Pipeline?

Presented by Dr. Augustina Reyes

This talk will explore school discipline data to show that the way children are treated in school can help to set them on a path for later in life.  Students who are suspended in school are more likely to be arrested than students who are never suspended. Join us in following the school-to-prison pipeline from state policy to district policy to school leadership practices to the detention center. 

Followed by refreshments and a Q&A with Dr. Reyes.

For more information contact Steven Villano at villanos@uhd.edu

item.title: Documentary Film Screening - Black America Since MLK: And Still I Rise (2/22/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 2/22/2018 Start Time: 1:00 PM
End Date: 2/22/2018 End Time: 2:30 PM

Discussion Facilitated by Dr. Jonathan Chism, Assistant Professor of History

This film explores the last five decades of black history since the civil rights era and the death of Martin Luther King Jr. Narrated by the esteemed Henry Louis Gates Jr., the film encourages deep reflection on questions such as: “How far have we come toward racial equality since the civil rights era? What does it mean to be black today? How have we, as a nation, elected a black President while events like those in Ferguson continue to occur?”​

item.title: Speed Networking Experience Mixer (3/1/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 3/1/2018 Start Time: 5:30 PM
End Date: 3/1/2018 End Time: 7:30 PM

Is it hard for you to tell others what you’re good at?

Does the idea of an interview make you nervous? Yes.

Then the Speed Networking Experience (S.N.E.) is for you.

Learn how to effectively network through various workshops leading up to the Speed Networking Experience Mixer.

 Please take the time to RSVP @ tinyurl.com/SNESP18

We encourage all students to attend the following optional open events, which will prepare you for the Speed Networking Mixer on Thurs., Mar. 1 @ 5:30 PM – 7:30 PM! 

The Quest for the Perfect Suit: Wed., Feb. 12 @ 11:30 AM / Vlog @uhdcareer

Personal Branding: Thurs., Feb. 15 @ 11:30 AM / Career Development Center S402

Online Branding: Thurs., Feb. 15 @ 1:00 PM / Career Development Center S402

Elevator Pitch - Tues., Feb. 20 @ 11:30 AM / Career Development Center S402

Networking - Tues., Feb. 20 @ 1:00 PM / Career Development Center S402

The Speed Networking Mixer is a free business social where you can apply your new found knowledge in a safe and judgment-free zone! Practice your networking skills with professionals at this fun and interactive event!

  • For freshmen and sophomore non-business majors.

  • Business casual attire is required.

  • Must stay for the entire event.

  • Space is limited!

 For more information, contact Jesse Lopez at 713-221-8980.

item.description:
Start Date: 3/2/2018 Start Time: 11:00 AM
End Date: 3/2/2018 End Time: 12:00 PM
The Retention Center provides an easy way for you to discover which students in your course are at risk. Based on preconfigured rules and rules you create, students’ engagement and participation are visually displayed, quickly alerting you to potential risk. From the Retention Center, you can communicate with struggling students and help them take immediate action for improvement. You can begin using the Retention Center features immediately—no setup required.

item.description:
Start Date: 3/19/2018 Start Time: 12:00 PM
End Date: 3/19/2018 End Time: 2:30 PM
A disturbing expose of sexual assaults on American college campuses, their institutional cover-ups, and the devastating toll they take on students and their families. This film combines actual footage with first-person testimonies as it follows the lives of several undergraduate assault survivors attempting to pursue--despite incredible push back, harassment, and trauma--both their educations and justice.

item.description:

     Insurance and Risk Management students will learn about every aspect of risk management from a prestigious international corporate risk manager. 
Spencer Educational Foundation provides the IRM Center an annual grant each year to host a "Risk Manager in Residence". 
      Rich Johanson, Manager, Risk Management at General Dynamics Corporation will visit our campus to speak about the risk management program of such a dynamic corporation with major products including aerospace (Gulf Stream), combat vehicles, military ships for the US Navy, IT and others.

item.title: Film Screening & Discussion - The Mask You Live In (3/21/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 3/21/2018 Start Time: 12:00 PM
End Date: 3/21/2018 End Time: 2:00 PM
This film follows boys and young men as they struggle to stay true to themselves while negotiating America's limited definition of masculinity. Pressured by the media, their peer groups, and even the adults in their lives, these young men confront messages encouraging them to disconnect from their emotions, to devalue authentic friendships, to objectify women, and to resolve conflicts through violence. These gender stereotypes interconnect with race, class, and circumstance, creating a maze of identity issues boys and young men must navigate to become "REAL" men.

item.description:

End Date: 3/21/2018 End Time: 1:00 PM

item.description:
Start Date: 3/21/2018 Start Time: 3:00 PM
End Date: 3/21/2018 End Time: 5:00 PM

Miss-Representation is a documentary arguing that the media--the most powerful communication force in our society--continues to fail women by enculturating them--along with men--to believe that a woman's value remains primarily her beauty, youth, and sexuality/sensuality. Join us for a thoughtful film experience that will lead to a lively discussion.

item.title: Building Gator Grit: Cultivating Positive Learning Environments to Enhance Motivation for Diverse Le (3/22/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 3/22/2018 Start Time: 2:00 PM
End Date: 3/22/2018 End Time: 5:00 PM

Building Gator Grit: Cultivating Positive Learning Environments to Enhance Motivation for Diverse Learners

 

Session Description: Grit, resilience, mindset – attitudes and beliefs that signal intrinsic motivation – have recently become widely recognized in popular culture as important ingredients of success. However, research on the relationship between intrinsic motivation and academic success goes back many decades. Much is known about the value and practice of fostering motivation among diverse learners (including age, cultural, and socio-economic diversity). This workshop provides a foundation for faculty and staff to reflect on how our own mindset influences how we think about students and offers alternative practices in order to create positive learning environments. Grounded in culturally responsive pedagogy, the workshop will help participants develop a deeper understanding of the connections between student development, motivation, engaged learning, and culture. It helps answer two important, related questions: How might my practices be reframed to foster a learning environment which establishes inclusion, develops positive attitudes, and engenders competence? And, how can I as an individual faculty or staff contribute to increased enrollment and student persistence?







Facilitator: Jonathan Grant Brown, Program Manager, AVID for Higher Education, http://www.avid.org/speakers-bureau.ashx







Location A-627, please register by March 21

item.title: Film Screening & Discussion - The Mask You Live In (3/22/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 3/22/2018 Start Time: 2:00 PM
End Date: 3/22/2018 End Time: 4:30 PM
This film follows boys and young men as they struggle to stay true to themselves while negotiating America's limited definition of masculinity. Pressured by the media, their peer groups, and event the adults in their lives, these young men confront messages encouraging them to disconnect from their emotions, to devalue authentic friendships, to objectify women, and to resolve conflicts through violence. These gender stereotypes interconnect with race, class, and circumstance, creating a maze of identity issues boys and young men must navigate to become "REAL" men.

item.title: Bayou Bash (3/22/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 3/22/2018 Start Time: 4:30 PM
End Date: 3/22/2018 End Time: 7:30 PM
018 Bayou Bash The University of Houston-Downtown (UHD) Office of Student Activities invites you to our annual Bayou Bash. Come and enjoy crawfish, cold beverages, live music, fun family activities and much more! Event Details: Wednesday, March 22, 2018 University of Houston, Downtown South Deck/Portico (Rain Location) from 4:30 to 7:30 p.m. Crawfish boil and Beer service begins at 5:00 p.m. Ticket Information: UHD Student tickets are FREE (with wristbrand). Your wristband serves as your ticket and includes crawfish, one beverage, and dessert (while supplies last). Wristbands are REQUIRED for food and beverages. Guest of UHD Students: $10.00 Advance Wristbands will be available for pick up beginning Monday, March 19. Bring your student ID and a copy of your eventbrite confirmation to Student Activities (S204) to get your wristband in advance and skip the lines! Beverages provided by: Saint Arnold Brewing Company and Coca Cola Music provided by: Platinum Players Zydeco Band Registration: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2018-bayou-bash-tickets-44008834609 What is included with my registration? 1/2 pound of Crawfish (1) Beverage Complimentary souvenir t-shirt or commemorative koozie (while supplies last) Interested in serving as a volunteer? Please stop by the Office of Student Activities! Questions? Contact Student Activities at 713-221-8573, studentactivities@uhd.edu or visit room S204.

Yoga is a class that involves mind-body connection which helps develop focus, balance, strength & flexibility.  With each pose, the body grows stronger and more toned to function better on a daily basis.  It is not just a form of exercise but a way of life.  This class is designed to provide instructions on the basic yoga methods, breathing and stretching.

item.title: Scholarly and Creative Activities Showcase (3/29/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 3/29/2018 Start Time: 5:30 PM
End Date: 3/29/2018 End Time: 7:00 PM

College of Public Service faculty who have been awarded internal funding initiatives to support innovative projects in curriculum, research, service, and community partnerships will present at this showcase of scholarly and creative activities. Guests are invited to participate in a roundtable discuss with faculty who will share insights about their work from conception of the idea, to development of the proposal, to the execution of the project. 

Featured Faculty and their Projects Include:

  • Dr. Franklin Allaire, “Exploring teacher Identity Construction and Negotiation: A Longitudinal Study”
  • Dr. Beth Gilmore, “Police Views on Policing”  (with student, James Holt)
  • Dr. Angie Goins, “Geriatric Social Work Education: A Historical Perspective on the Social Response to Aging”
  • Dr. Heather Goltz, Pap Testing Among Older Adults, also, highlighting a case study of Sexual and Gender Minorities Who are Bladder Cancer Survivors
  • Drs. Laura Mitchell and Jackie Sack, “Co-Teaching Learning Environment: Pre-Service Bilingual Generalists Explore Their Language and Math Identities in a Required Math Methods Course”

item.title: Helena Maria Viramontes:A Reading and Book Signing (3/29/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 3/29/2018 Start Time: 6:00 PM
End Date: 3/29/2018 End Time: 7:00 PM
Novelist Helena Maria Viramontes is a major figure in American and Mexican American Literature, who is particularly important in developments in Chicana feminism from the 1980s forward. Named a USA Ford Fellow in Literature for 2007, she has received numerous awards, including the John Dos Passos Prize for literature.

Author of Under the Feet of Jesus, The Moths and Other Stories, and Their Dogs Came with Them, Viramontes is currently Professor of Creative Writing at Cornell University.

Registration occurs on site. UHD students and alumni, check with your Career Development Center about the availability of transportation from UH-Downtown which may require registration.

Business professional attire required; if you are unsure speak to the Career Development Center.

Research employers ahead of time and understand positions available prior to approaching them at the job fair.

item.title: First-Year Student Success: Teaching Time Management & Behavioral Change (4/5/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 4/5/2018 Start Time: 11:45 AM
End Date: 4/5/2018 End Time: 1:15 PM

First-Year Student Success: Teaching Time Management & Behavioral Change

Lunch & Learn Event: Webinar Viewing & Discussion

Thursday, April 5, 2018, 11:45am to 1:15pm

Join your colleagues as we view and discuss the ideas presented in the webinar below. Lunch will be served. Please reserve your seat before Monday, April 2. Attendance is limited to 20 registrants.

Session description: Researchers argue that self-regulatory behaviors are at the heart college success. In fact, studies indicate that the ability to manage time and combat procrastination is more predictive of college achievement than standardized tests and high school grades. Unfortunately, many undergraduate students enter post-secondary institutions without having mastered the basic study skills and self-regulatory behaviors that foster college success. The inability to master these behavioral and cognitive skill sets contributes to negative outcomes ranging from compromised immune systems to damaged relationships to impeded academic performance. This webinar explores self-regulatory behaviors from several theoretical frameworks and provides participants with practical strategies and tools to get even their most-at-risk students to break the cycle of procrastination and move toward behavior change.

Session outcomes:

• Examine basic research findings

• Explore behavior change model

• Critique & understand flaws in current time management pedagogy

• Identify psychodynamics of procrastination from different theoretical frameworks

• Analyze & understand the cycle of procrastination

• Improve strategies for helping your students combat procrastination

• Discover tips to implement effective pedagogical tools immediately



For more info, contact Dr. Bill Waller (wallerw@uhd.edu / 713.221.8404



Room TBD.

item.title: The Scholar Identity Model: Black Male Sucess in the K-12 Context (4/9/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 4/9/2018 Start Time: 3:30 PM
End Date: 4/9/2018 End Time: 5:00 PM
'The Scholar Identity Model: Black Male Sucess in the K-12 Context Lecture' The University of Houston-Downtown College of Public Service and the Department of Minority Male Recruitment will be presenting the, 'The Scholar Identity Model: Black Male Success in the K-12 Context Lecture', featuring author and scholar, Dr. Gilman Whiting, Director of the Scholar Identity Institute, and Associate Professor of the African-American and Diaspora Studies and Callie House Research Center at Vanderbilt University Date: Monday, April 9, 2018 Address: Commerce Building, 1002 Commerce Street, Houston, TX 77002 Room Location: Commerce -C100 Lecture #1: 3:30pm-5:00pm –Community leaders, faculty and staff Lecture #2: 5:30pm-7:00pm –Student session only Dr. Gilman W. Whiting is an Associate Professor of African American and Diaspora Studies and Director of Graduate Studies. His areas of research include: race, sports, and American culture; educational disparity; welfare reform and fatherhood initiatives; special and gifted education. He has authored over forty scholarly articles in journals such as Roeper Review, Journal for Secondary Gifted Education, and The International Journal of Sport and Society, and book chapters. Dr. Whiting is the creator of the Scholar Identity Model™ and consults with school districts nationally and internationally. He is also the founding chair of the Achievement Gap Institute for the Peabody College of Education. Please follow the link below to RSVP https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-scholar-identity-model-black-male-success-in-the-k-12-context-tickets-44454616956?utm-medium=discovery&utm-campaign=social&utm-content=attendeeshare&aff=escb&utm-source=cp&utm-term=listing

item.title: HIPs & Community Engagement Showcase (4/10/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 4/10/2018 Start Time: 8:00 AM
End Date: 4/10/2018 End Time: 3:30 PM

The Center for Teaching and Learning Excellence (CTLE) and Center for Community Engagement and Service Learning (CCESL) call  for proposals from UHD faculty (tenured, tenure-track, non-tenure track, and adjunct), staff, and students interested in presenting their work at the UHD HIPs and Community Engagement Showcase to be held April 10, 2018 from 8:00 am to 3:30 pm in The Welcome Center (Milam/Travis). Faculty and staff presentations should be focused on approaches to implementing High-Impact Practices (HIPs), Service Learning (SL), or Community Engagement (CE) in curricular or co-curricular settings. Students are encouraged to co-present with faculty and staff or present their projects done in SL-designated courses or through CE grants. Applicants are not required to have a CTLE or CCESL-funded project to present at the showcase but those with currently or previously funded projects are strongly encouraged to present.  

 

Proposal Submission Process:

Attach a presentation title and proposal abstract (200- 250 words) using the online application form. You will need to include the following information on the form.

o   Your name, affiliation, email, and names/info. for each co-presenter

o   Format of presentation

·         11:30 am-12:45 pm – Poster presentations

·         2:30-3:30 pm – Round-Table Quick Talks - 10 minutes repeated 3-5 times at a table of 4-6 participants

Call for Proposals:
https://tinyurl.com/hipsceshowcase2018  

Questions

Questions about the showcase or proposal submission process should be directed to the Center for Teaching and Learning Excellence, ctle@uhd.edu or x8280.

item.title: The Sustainability Initiative Student Proposals (4/30/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 4/30/2018 Start Time: 7:30 AM
End Date: 4/30/2018 End Time: 11:59 PM
UHD’s Center for Urban Agriculture and Sustainability (CUAS) has the vision of providing Houston citizens with the knowledge and resources to build sustainable neighborhoods throughout the city. CUAS is committed to developing sustainable solutions and raising student awareness in order to create stable urban ecosystems, reduce carbon emissions and increase urban food production. The Sustainability Initiative was created so that UHD students can carry out their own sustainability projects.

This initiative originated from a student government proposal for a sustainability tax to be added to student fees. The tax could be used to fund student projects that would improve the sustainability of UHD or the surrounding region. In lieu of this tax, the UHD Administration has agreed to fund this student initiative for two years to determine if there is student interest in self-directed sustainability projects.

Proposal Focus
The focus of the proposal can be any project that will promote sustainability practices at UHD or the greater Houston community. Projects are welcome from enrolled students in all colleges of the university and may focus on subjects such as educational campaigns, small business consulting, green initiatives, new technologies or new UHD resources such as new UHD infrastructure, art or digital materials.
Benefits of Applying for this Initiative
  • A student or group of students (up to 3) can design a project that creates or builds on sustainable practices within UHD or the larger Houston community.
  • Students will gain experience running an independent project (with the help of a faculty mentor) and make valuable connections to the community or industry.
  • Funds will be made available for students to carry out the project. 
Learn More

item.description:

End Date: 7/17/2018 End Time: 6:30 PM
Interested in transferring to UHD? Transfer Thursday is your one stop to learn you everything you need to know to be a UHD Gator!

You'll be able to:
  • have one-on-one admissions counseling
  • learn about scholarships and financial aid
  • submit documentation for expedited processing
  • and much more!

RSVP for the information session.

Tuesday, July 17, 5:30 p.m. - 6:30 pm.
UHD Northwest
20515 SH249
Building 12
Houston, TX 77070

item.title: Assessment of Education Programs (10/30/2018)
item.description:
Start Date: 10/30/2018
End Date: 10/30/2018
With the exception of the General Education and Developmental Education programs, program faculty submit the annual assessment report to the department chair or dean (for those programs which fall outside the departmental structure) by October 30 of the academic year following the year in which the work was assessed.
